Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transportation Network Identification: Information Fusion via Stochastic Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowledge of the traffic network state, in terms of, for example, network-level traffic flow and travel time, is critically needed for network monitoring and effective transportation system management and control under both normal and extreme conditions. Recent technological advances, such as mobile sensing and connected vehicles, can generate big data. In general, this research aims to address challenges on how to best use these inherently large-scale, dynamic, and heterogeneous (multi-source) data streams. More specifically, the project seeks an innovative systems approach for estimating the statistical properties of traffic flow and travel time via integrating various traffic data pieces over a complex network structure (such as traffic counts collected by fixed sensors and individual "urban digital footprints" collected by Bluetooth tag reader logs, cellular phone records, and global positioning system traces). A successful outcome of this project will directly benefit society through more effective utilization of information, and thus more sustainable and efficient transportation system planning and operations. This project includes curricula development and student mentoring activities that help better prepare next-generation transportation professionals for challenges brought by the big data era.

Mathematically, the question addressed in this project is: Given directly measurable network parameters x, which tend to be localized and incomplete, how can one infer global network parameters y that are often difficult to be measured directly, with the mapping between y and x built on a complex network structure? This problem category has broad applications in transportation, communication, and energy networks; although, the focus in this project is on transportation networks. Built on knowledge in transportation network science, stochastic optimization, variational analysis, and non-parametric estimation, the research team will pursue the following main tasks: (1) Creation of an optimization framework for network identification based on stochastic optimization and non-parametric estimation; (2) Integration of multi-source traffic data (hard information) with domain-knowledge-based soft information via constraints and functional mapping; (3) Linking historical-data-based offline estimation with real-time information for online estimation and decision support through Bayesian methods; (4) Testing and validating the project's methods using both real-world data and computer simulations. This research establishes a unifying theoretical framework for traffic network identification that integrates knowledge in transportation network science and data analytics. By providing greater modeling flexibility than existing methods in handling various types of hard and soft information and in capturing transportation network physics, this new method ushers a paradigm-shift in traffic network system identification. The project also creates a real-world engineering platform for strengthening connections between optimization and statistics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the emergence of new technologies and systems in transportation (e.g., connected/ automated vehicles and ridesourcing services), data are becoming increasingly available for transportation, including both traditional flow data and ?big data? from these new systems. This NSF research aimed to develop the mathematical foundation, models, and algorithms to fuse heterogeneous, multi-sourced data and local knowledge for global information at the transportation network level. This resulted in new methods and mathematical paradigms in transportation science, which have the potential to transform the way how data and knowledge are integrated in transportation and other fields.

The research benefited many audiences, including undergraduate and graduate students, researchers, and practitioners in transportation and data analytics. Graduate and undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups, participated in the research. Results from this research were used to enhance undergraduate and graduate level courses. The research team worked closely with transportation agencies and the industry to make the best effort to convey research findings to decision makers, engineers, planners, the industry, and the academic communities.

Major findings of the research are summarized as follows:

  • Self-adaptive sampling (SAS) for mobile data collection: i) collecting wide-area, high-resolution mobile data (e.g., vehicle trajectories) can be resource-intensive (storage, transmission); ii) current practice is to use reduced sampling rates (e.g., a data point every 10 seconds) to balance data collection and resource consumption; iii) SAS can be developed based on the state of the vehicle (free-flowing, stopped, acceleration, deceleration, etc.); iv) SAS can be implemented in batch process or in real time; v) SAS can help achieve a fine balance for data reduction, accuracy, latency, and utility (i.e., the performance of data applications).
  • Travel time prediction: i) Fusing data from multi-sources, together with proper data analytics methods, can produce accurate and reliable travel time predictions; ii) the total system travel time reliability on a traffic network can be evaluated using distribution-free methods; iii) the travel time prediction and evaluation methods may be adopted by ridesourcing companies and traffic data providers to improve travel time information.

Major outcomes of the research are summarized as follows:

  • Research activities and results: this research produced three (3) journal papers (submitted or under review; see the detailed list below), one (1) working paper, one (1) conference proceeding paper, and a number of conference presentations.
  • Teaching activities: integrated research results to multiple courses the PI have taught in the last three years, including: Traffic Engineering, Traffic Control and Simulation, and Transportation System Analysis
  • Student advising: Three (3) Ph.D. students were (partially) supported by this research.  Two (2) of them are scheduled to graduate in the spring and fall of 2019, respectively. One (1) of them is ongoing, and plans to graduate in the fall of 2021.
  • Undergraduate research: Three (3) undergraduate students worked on this research through the REU fund of this project. One (1) of them are minority or underrepresented students. They were trained for mobile app development, traffic data collection, analysis, modeling, and presentation of research results.
  • Outreach: During the course of the project, the team conducted: (i) three (3) invited talks and many conference presentations; (ii)  multiple meetings with traffic/transportation practitioners on various topics of emerging transportation data and how to use the data to infer useful transportation information, including New York State Department of Transportation, Washington State Department of Transportation, Puget Sound Regional Council, Federal Highway Administrations, among others; (iii) dissemination of research results to the industry (e.g., Cuebig, Inrix, TrafficCast) by sharing research results (papers), via face-to-facing meetings, phone calls and emails, and collaborations on research proposals.

Publications (Journal and refereed conference proceedings):

1.       Ji. X.F.*, Ban, X., Li, M., Zhang, J., Ran, B., 2018. Moment-based travel time reliability assessment with Lasserre?s relaxation. Transpormetrica B: Dynamics, in press, DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/21680566.2018.1434018.

2.       Siddique, C.*, Ban, X., 2018. State-dependent Self-adaptive sampling of vehicle trajectory data. Submitted to Transportation Research Part C, 3rd revision.

3.       Siddique, C.*, Ban, X., 2018. Spectral analysis method for vehicle trajectory data, Submitted to the 23rd International Symposium on Transportation and Traffic Theory (ISTTT), 2nd revision.

4.       Li, W.*, Siddique, C.*, Ban, X., 2018. Data-driven travel time prediction from latent structures using multiple data sources. In Proceedings of the 7th International Workshop on Urban Computing (held in conjunction with the 24th ACM SIGKDD 2018), August 20, 2018, London, UK.

5.       Yang, Y., Fan, Y., Ban, X., 2018. Dynamic OD estimation under uncertainty: integrating hard data and soft information. Working paper.
